headline: Nice place to work
cons: Deal flow, exceptions are the rule

headline: not stable
pros: did not micromanage, free to leave to go hang out with clients
cons: leadership was unstable, was not upfront about legal issues

headline: Review
cons: Support Was awful from senior management

headline: Amazing
cons: very chaotic investment banking industry at the time

headline: Vice President
pros: Some good bankers work with the firm.
cons: Management is terrible and many of their deals are sub-par.

headline: Investment Advisor
pros: Interesting private equity transactions. Worked with some of the best VC in Silicon Valley. The founders and entrepreneurs would give interesting presentations about their companies.
cons: All the deals went bad. All the investors generally lost all their money. Never had a big winner at all. Company used very high-pressure sales techniques to sell these bad investments.

headline: No as bad as reported
pros:
Michael Dockendorf the new President is really turning this place around.
It is a New York Firm so if you are one of the boys it is quite fun.
The guys that gave this place a bad reputation have left.
cons: Lots of the guys will try and be your friend because they are not very good at their job.

headline: Great Business Model, horrible execution
pros: You have access to very exclusive venture backed opportunities that HNW clients normally wouldn't be exposed to.
cons: Nothing is ever what it seems.  Upper level management is inherently dishonest.  And you are absolutely on your own when it comes to sourcing leads.

headline: Poor
pros: Learn basic knowledge of selling and deal execution.
cons: At the time management was horrendous, from the VERY top down.

headline: Amazing partnerships with the best VCs...spoiled by used car salesmen aproach
pros: partnered with some of the top VC firms and worked on some really interesting capital raises.  Involved in numerous disruptive technologies
cons: the sr. management is potentially on the verge of criminal activity in regards to how they distribute information and advise their clients.  Management is street smart, but clearly lack the ability to run a VC firm/investment bank or whatever it is they want to call themselves.
